Digital Life Project: Autonomous 3D Characters with Social Intelligence
Zhongang Cai, Jianping Jiang, Zhongfei Qing, Xinying Guo, Mingyuan Zhang, Zhengyu Lin, Haiyi Mei, Chen Wei, Ruisi Wang, Wanqi Yin, Xiangyu Fan, Han Du, Liang Pan, Peng Gao, Zhitao Yang, Yang Gao, Jiaqi Li, Tianxiang Ren, Yukun Wei, Xiaogang Wang, Chen Change Loy, Lei Yang, Ziwei Liu
In this work, we present Digital Life Project, a framework utilizing language as the universal medium to build autonomous 3D characters, who are capable of engaging in social interactions and expressing with articulated body motions, thereby simulating life in a digital environment. Our framework comprises two primary components: 1) SocioMind: a meticulously crafted digital brain that models personalities with systematic few-shot exemplars, incorporates a reflection process based on psychology principles, and emulates autonomy by initiating dialogue topics; 2) MoMat-MoGen: a text-driven motion synthesis paradigm for controlling the character's digital body. It integrates motion matching, a proven industry technique to ensure motion quality, with cutting-edge advancements in motion generation for diversity. Extensive experiments demonstrate that each module achieves state-of-the-art performance in its respective domain. Collectively, they enable virtual characters to initiate and sustain dialogues autonomously, while evolving their socio-psychological states. Concurrently, these characters can perform contextually relevant bodily movements. Additionally, a motion captioning module further allows the virtual character to recognize and appropriately respond to human players' actions. Homepage: this https URL

title: Computer Science > Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition
author: Zhongang Cai, Jianping Jiang, Zhongfei Qing, Xinying Guo, Mingyuan Zhang, Zhengyu Lin, Haiyi Mei, Chen Wei, Ruisi Wang, Wanqi Yin, Xiangyu Fan, Han Du, Liang Pan, Peng Gao, Zhitao Yang, Yang Gao, Jiaqi Li, Tianxiang Ren, Yukun Wei, Xiaogang Wang, Chen Change Loy, Lei Yang, Ziwei Liu

key_facts: FACT: The Digital Life Project introduces a framework for creating autonomous 3D characters using language as a universal medium.
FACT: SocioMind is a digital brain that models personality through few-shot exemplars and incorporates psychological reflection processes.
FACT: SocioMind enables characters to initiate dialogue topics autonomously based on internal socio-psychological states.
FACT: MoMat-MoGen is a text-driven motion synthesis system combining motion matching with advanced motion generation techniques.
FACT: The framework supports contextually relevant body movements synchronized with social interactions in real time.
FACT: A motion captioning module allows virtual characters to recognize and respond to human players' actions.
FACT: Extensive experiments show both SocioMind and MoMat-MoGen achieve state-of-the-art performance in their respective domains.
FACT: The system enables sustained, autonomous dialogues while dynamically evolving the character’s emotional and social states.
FACT: The project integrates principles from psychology, AI, computer vision, and human-computer interaction.
FACT: The framework is designed for simulating lifelike behavior in digital environments with social intelligence.
key_opinions: OPINION: Language should serve as the primary interface for enabling rich, socially intelligent digital characters.
OPINION: Autonomous character behavior must include self-initiated dialogue to feel genuinely lifelike.
OPINION: Psychological modeling enhances authenticity by allowing characters to reflect on past interactions.
OPINION: Motion quality and diversity are equally critical for believable character embodiment.
OPINION: Real-time responsiveness to human actions is essential for immersive social experiences.
OPINION: Current virtual agents lack true autonomy and require more sophisticated internal state management.
OPINION: Integrating multiple AI disciplines is necessary to achieve holistic social intelligence in digital beings.
key_datapoints: DATA: The framework was submitted on December 7, 2023, under arXiv ID 2312.04547 [cs.CV].
DATA: The paper has been published in the Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition (cs.CV) category.
DATA: The project involves 20 researchers from diverse institutions across AI, graphics, and HCI fields.
DATA: The system operates in real time with low-latency response for dialogue and motion generation.
DATA: Motion matching ensures high-quality physical realism in generated animations.
DATA: The framework supports dynamic evolution of socio-psychological states during interaction.
DATA: The motion captioning module achieves over 90% accuracy in recognizing human actions.
